results.title: Felix the Cat
results.brief_description: A bag of high flying adventure with Felix the Cat. See Felix pull all elevators and airplanes out of his magic bag of tricks and fly to the moon with Pointdexter. Watch Felix capture Rock Bottom and delight in the antics of the professor. It’s all here in an hour of fun! Rated: G

results.title: Felidae
results.creator_credit: Vanessa White, Sarah Watt and Victorian College of the Arts, School of Film and Television
results.brief_description: This hand-drawn animation tells the story of two people’s sightings of a big-cat or panther in the Dandenongs of Melbourne. The visuals accompanying the voice-overs serve to add to the story in more abstract terms with painted film and iconic images of panthers intermixed with the voices.

results.title: Felicia's journey
results.creator_credit: Atom Egoyan, Bruce Davey, Screenventures, Alliance Atlantis and Marquis Films
results.brief_description: Atom Egoyan’s second literary adaptation (“The Sweet Hereafter” was the first) is a dark yet comic tale of the powerful influence of childhood and the search for contentment in life’s journey. Pregnant and alone, Felicia (Elaine Cassidy) leaves her native home of Ireland in search of Johnny, father of her unborn child. Arriving in Birmingham with few clues as to his location, she meets factory canteen manager Mr Hilditch (Bob Hoskins), a seemingly benevolent gent who offers to help Felicia find lodgings and her love. Hilditchs’ home is a time capsule of 1950’s homewear, and he spends his evenings watching footage of his mother, Gala (Arsinee Khanjian), a successful television chef, and himself as a young child in the background. The relationship revealed throughout the footage is deliciously tinged with antagonism and pain, something that remains with Hilditch throughout his adult life and appears to have influenced his relationship with women. Felicia is not the first wayward soul assisted by Mr Hilditch, as it is revealed he has recorded the innermost thoughts of numerous other women he has picked up in his car - Felicia appears to be the next in line. Cast also includes Peter McDonald, Gerard McSorley and Claire Benedict. Based on the novel by William Trevor.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Atom Egoyan, Bruce Davey, Screenventures, Alliance Atlantis and Marquis Films

results.title: Feiz, the last expert
results.creator_credit: Milan Chupurdija, Ceda Oketich and Perspective Films
results.brief_description: This film portrays a man and his son in Belgrade, Yugoslavia, who scratch out a living by travelling the streets in search of pots and pans to repair. The occupation of “tinker” is the focus of this film, one which is seen as diminishing.

results.title: Feet first
results.creator_credit: Clyde Bruckman and Harold Lloyd Corporation
results.brief_description: In Harold Lloyd’s second ‘talkie’ he plays a hopelessly inept shoe clerk, determined to improve himself. Masquerading as a millionare he stows away on a cruise ship but gets dumped overboard in a mail sack. A highlight of the film is a high risk scene on the building scaffolding of a skyscraper where our hapless hero unexpectedly finds himself. Cast includes Harold Lloyd, Barbara Kent, Robert McWade and Lillian Leighton.

results.title: Feet and footwear: caring for your feet
results.creator_credit: Ivan Gaal and TV Ed Productions
results.brief_description: Thomas is one-year old and is fitted for his first pair of shoes. It is an unhappy experience for him and raises questions regarding why we need footwear and why we need to care for our feet. Two podiatrists, a shoe manufacturer and a shoe retailer/fitter share their knowledge and advice relating to feet and footwear.

results.title: Feelings: what are you afraid of?
results.creator_credit: Abram Murray and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Helps the young viewer understand that everyone experiences fear at some time and that being afraid need not be a subject of embarrassment. Shows a number of children discussing their fears. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Feelings: don't stay mad
results.creator_credit: Abram Murray and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Discusses the fact that people should not let feelings grow until they are overwhelmed by them. Suggests that anger can be talked out or acted out in positive ways. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Feelings. Part 2
results.creator_credit: Justin Shortal, Cate Fyffe, CVV Productions and Environment Audio Visuals
results.brief_description: A series of vignettes is presented each of which focuses on one of the following feelings: anger; jealousy; rejection and loneliness. The dramatised situations are usually open-ended thus providing a stimulus for discussion. High school students are used to play the roles. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Feelings. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Justin Shortal, Cate Fyffe, CVV Productions and Environment Audio Visuals
results.brief_description: Presents seven separate incidents each with its own title and discussion questions: Smoking and drinking; Adolescents joining in with family activities; Cheating in exams; Aspirations; Losing a loved pet; Friendship and trust; Infatuation and embarrassment. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.
